content.question: The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a continuous derivative. If <math alttext="f of 0, equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="f of 2, equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>, and <math alttext="the integral from, 0 to 2, of, f of x, d x, equals 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></math>, what is <math alttext="the integral from, 0 to 2, of x, times f prime of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo largeop="true">⋅</mo><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> ?

topic.text: 6.11: (BC ONLY) Integrating Using Integration by Parts
